item.title: Comment on Thursday assorted links by peri
item.description:
I don't know. Back when the numbers of homeless were so much smaller, among the men - the women were always obviously crazy - you kind of got an "urban outdoorsman" vibe. They actually carried their stuff on their back, instead of in five shopping carts and a kiddie bike roped together. They seemed to know and practice the art, many of them, of blending in.
I remember walking through a park and noticing a couple homeless guys actually cooking a squirrel on the charcoal grill.
It doesn't seem much like that now.
Even when they are sitting around, in their chairs, with a rug and a TV, on the actual overpass of the freeway, smiling and laughing - they remind me most of the crazy guy who used to be in the laundromate all the time when I was doing laundry, *pretending* to hold a conversation on the payphone. For hours.
I do think they have some skills, though. They are hardy, obviously, and to an extent brave since one of them kills another one approximately every four or five days, you know, just like their community was Stars Hollow.

But overall, the salient fact is they are drawn to precincts where rich people are. Full stop. They are never anywhere else but there.

That's not something you could have ever said about a "frontiersman".

item.title: Comment on Ryan Bourne on the British growth deterioration by M
item.description:
It's for the birds as to whether differences in planning law make the UK have a role to play in the long term, static, productivity divergence of UK from the United States.

But I don't really see how it can be such a factor explain a lower trend growth specifically after about 2006. It's very "Just So", and there's a reason why it's little invoked in academic analyses of the productivity trend.

If you even believe these stories about how planning permission makes everything impossible relative to a zoning system. Back when World Bank used to publish a
Time required to build a warehouse (days) metric as part of their Ease of Doing Business project, they found that UK had a similar time to USA. The burden of planning permission regulations between countries are not so easily comparable to estimate their impact.

Alternatively OECD gives a measure of Land Governance Regulation within housing policy toolkit (see here for UK). And while the UK is high on this, it has little relationship with housing costs - graph - with countries such as Canada and Ireland with high costs scoring low on their index.

item.title: Comment on My Conversation with the excellent Coleman Hughes by Clerk
item.description:
Coleman's answer was good. I'd add that in general, we should downgrade individual people's political beliefs significantly in our assessments of them. Unless you're an academic or policy/politics professional, the amount you actually know is close to nil. Random people's views have near zero impact on the world. And they usually have at least one batshit political position that doesn't make sense. Just ignore all of it.

Much more important is how they deal with people interpersonally. How do they treat or talk about their parents, siblings, friends, and the waitress or barista on your date? How do they treat you? How do they use their time and what's important to them? These things are usually not too related to politics, and also make a real difference in a relationship.

I have to disagree that Coleman is a lone voice crying out in the wilderness. The media landscape is awash with classical liberals. They're all guests on each other's podcasts! The whole ecosystem is a rotating cast of the same podcasts guests, each one propping up the other's show!

Were his schtick simply repeating the greatest hits of libertarians of yore, I'd be critical!

item.title: Comment on My Conversation with the excellent Coleman Hughes by Tony
item.description:
one of the best convos with Tyler ever. a lot of paternal empathy there -- that's not a criticism really of the convo. As a fellow autodidact, I really feel a struggle in Hughes to assert his own voice rather than to put out a pastiche or tapestry of the voices of others in order to connect. Hughes' vocabulary and mien were all focused (he might say monomaniacally) on matching and mirroring Tyler's. I used to do that. Mohammed Ali's line was float like a butterfly, sting like a bee. But Ali had a firm voice, and his miming was an overlay and a strategy, not the main thing. Hughes is floating so nothing hits him directly. And his own convos podcast, conceptually, just doubles down on the matching and mirroring thing. On the other hand, the Tyler convo with Haidt shows another possibility in convos that I very much doubt Hughes is ready to show. In my mid-thirties, a therapist changed my life when he said my own habits of miming and mirroring were dangerous long term. I hope Hughes sees that someday too and starts to assert his own voice politically. Doing so might move him further from a Beastie Boy, closer to an Eminem.

item.title: Comment on My Conversation with the excellent Coleman Hughes by PHinton
item.description:
> namely that he doesn't have much to say that hasn't already been said by others in more interesting or charismatic ways.

The problem is that those that have said this before are gone. It's important to have a person able to go onto The View and discuss these things so that a new batch of housewives can get the exposure. Sadly, in the last 10 years we've gone from treating everyone the same to giving those with a certain hair type a big advantage at every phase of life. From college admission to jobs. And the 20-something thinks this is a good thing. They have zero understanding this was precisely what Jim Crow was. Because people like MLK aren't around to go on The View and talk about this.

I just re-watched Milton Friedman on Phil Donohue from 1979. What an excellent interview (he was on twice). TC probably isn't saying anything new either. But he can go out and channel Friedman on some topics. And that's important. And Friedman wasn't new either. "I, Pencil" was written by someone I don't remember. But Friedman took and and used it as a very effective teaching tool.

Nothing is new. It's all about having a stable of folks that can channel these messages to the masses.
